title: New Parent Charged in College-Admissions Cheating Case
summary: Chinese woman allegedly paid $400,000 to William 'Rick' Singer to get her son fraudulently admitted to UCLA. U.S. prosecutors charged an additional mother in the college-admissions cheating case, alleging she paid $400,000 to get her son into UCLA and marking the 52nd person to face criminal prosecution in the sprawling scheme.

title: Fed Intervenes to Curb Soaring Short-Term Borrowing Costs
summary: For first time since 2008 the central bank injects funds into money markets after a sudden shortage of cash. For the first time in more than a decade, the Federal Reserve injected cash into money markets Tuesday to pull down interest rates and said it would do so again Wednesday after technical factors led to a sudden shortfall of cash.

title: New York Bans Sale of Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: Health council says intent is to stem rising use among minors. Amid a rash of pulmonary illnesses and several deaths in the U.S. linked to vaping and e-cigarette usage, New York state health officials on Tuesday passed an emergency regulation temporarily banning the sale of flavored e-cigarettes and nicotine e-liquids.

title: U.S., Saudi Military Forces Failed to Detect Attack on Oil Facilities
summary: Drones and missiles-which officials increasingly believe were launched from Iran-appeared to have flown low to the ground so that they weren't detected by radar or defense systems. WASHINGTON-U.S. and Saudi military forces and their elaborate air-defense systems failed to detect the launch of airstrikes aimed at Saudi Arabian oil facilities, allowing dozens of drones and missiles to hit their targets, U.S. officials said.

title: SEC Charges Former CEO for Alleged Misstatements About Existence of CFO
summary: Viking Energy's auditors never communicated with the finance chief, a regulator says. The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the former chief executive of an oil-and-gas production company with fraud for allegedly falsifying the existence of its previous finance chief.

title: Spanish Court Explains Rebuffing of U.S. Extradition Request
summary: Former Venezuelan spy chief, released Monday, was long sought by U.S. prosecutors. Spain's National Court said it rejected the U.S.'s extradition request for a former head of Venezuela's military intelligence wanted on drug-trafficking charges because it found the request by American prosecutors to be politically motivated.

title: Providence Equity Closes Eighth Flagship Fund Above $6 Billion
summary: One of the oldest sector-specialist private-equity firms continued its post-financial-crisis fundraising rebound. Providence Equity Partners, a private-equity firm known for its early bets on companies such as Hulu and Ironman, has raised more than $6 billion for its latest flagship fund, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: 'What It Takes' Review: The Ingredients of Success
summary: Even as a raw youth with no Wall Street experience, Stephen Schwarzman was clearly going places. Blackstone today is an imposing ﬁnancial ediﬁce.. On Oct. 15, 1987, a Thursday, the fledgling Blackstone private-equity firm locked up nearly $800 million of investors' capital. That was short of the firm's brash $1 billion goal for its initial fund, but markets seemed nervous and so were the firm's founders: the elder statesman Pete Peterson and his ambitious younger partner Stephen Schwarzman.

title: FedEx Hit by Trade Tensions and Split With Amazon
summary: Delivery giant says global economic uncertainty and split with Amazon cut into profit at its struggling Express division. FedEx Corp. sharply cut its profit forecast for the year as it faces higher costs to expand services, lower revenue from cutting ties with Amazon.com Inc. and a worsening economic backdrop, sending shares of the delivery company plummeting 10% in after-hours trading.

summary: The city, citing progress, hasn't cut funding to institutions, despite findings in a July report that mirrored those in 2016. Mayor Bill de Blasio threatened in 2017 to pull funding to New York City's top cultural institutions, if they didn't diversify their staff.

title: Labor Shortage May Imperil Growth
summary: A lack of qualified workers boosts wages but makes it hard for businesses to expand.. Good help is hard to find-and increasingly so in today's economy. According to a monthly survey by the National Federation of Independent Businesses, "a record percentage of small business owners reported having difficulties finding qualified workers in August." It's been the top problem in the survey since January 2018. Policy makers need to listen.

title: As New Hampshire Goes . . .
summary: Likely voters in the state's Democratic primary seek a moderate nominee.. America is diverse, and that goes for its states as well as the population as a whole. Still, some states are more pivotal-and representative-than others, which is why focusing on them can tell us something important about the direction of the country. New Hampshire is one such state.

title: The Calls That Don't Get Made
summary: It's an inside joke-and the only other person who got it is no longer alive.. 'Tim, get your head off the wall."

title: The Business Roundtable's Recipe for Confusion
summary: When companies try to do the government's job, inefficiency and uncertainty result.. The Business Roundtable released a statement last month, signed by 181 CEOs, with the stated goal of "modernizing its principles on the role of a corporation." The organization has issued various pronouncements for more than 40 years, all of which have endorsed maximizing shareholder value as the primary objective of a for-profit corporate enterprise. Those days are gone. "While each of our individual companies serves its own corporate purpose, we share a fundamental commitment to all of our stakeholders," the statement reads. The Roundtable defines "stakeholders" as "customers, employees, suppliers, communities and shareholders." Notice who comes last.

title: Not All Gifted Children Are From Affluent Families
summary: To help the poor rise, the education system needs to 'raise the ceiling' as well as 'lift the floor.'. All of us understand why so many discussions about K-12 education center on bringing low-achieving students up to speed. How could they not? Despite massive increases in school spending over the past half-century, the U.S. Department of Education reports that nearly two-thirds of our youngsters score below the proficient level on national reading tests, and large socioeconomic disparities persist. Obviously, this is a problem.

title: Don't Panic Over the Saudi Attack and the Oil Supply
summary: OPEC would have had to cut output anyway, given the dramatic increase in American production.. The attack on Saudi Arabia's oil infrastructure last weekend took out about half of the kingdom's production capacity. Yet the market reaction was muted, with global oil prices rising only to where they were in May. Markets seem to recognize that Saudi Arabia and other members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will eventually need to curtail their oil production one way or the other to make room for the explosion of U.S. production. If they don't, prices will collapse.

title: Cokie Roberts, Longtime Political Journalist, Dies at 75
summary: She chronicled Washington from Jimmy Carter to Donald Trump for NPR and ABC News. title: Why Jay Leno Invests in Cars, Not Stocks
summary: For the 'Jay Leno's Garage' host, there's no time for trips, no room for boring cars and nothing like driving with a burger in his hand. The former "Tonight Show" host claims cruising its streets is a major selling point of the city.

title: In Evergreen, Colo., a Community That Stays True to Itself
summary: Residents of this town just west of Denver enjoy abundant wildlife and space, as well as an authentic vibe in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains. Just west of Denver in Colorado's Rocky Mountain foothills, Evergreen is the kind of place where families have lived for generations. The Western community with a charming main street dates back to 1859 when people moved here to ranch. Around the turn of the century, due to Evergreen's proximity to the state capital, city folks started migrating to the region to build summer homes and hunting cabins. After an alpine reservoir was filled in 1928 to create Evergreen Lake, the area increased in popularity. Today houses still sit on ample acreage, and wildlife-like elk and bears-is omnipresent. This gives the town of about 9,000 people a middle-of-nowhere vibe despite being only roughly 30 to 40 minutes from both downtown Denver and popular ski areas further west. It's one of just a few foothill enclaves that has not changed drastically over the years, meaning despite its glitzy residents, Evergreen remains real as it gets.

title: Trump Says China Is Buying U.S. Farm Products
summary: President signals optimism a U.S.-China trade deal will be reached before the election. WASHINGTON-President Trump said China has started to buy U.S. agricultural products, and signaled optimism that his administration will be able to sign a trade deal with China before the 2020 presidential election.

summary: It's a black hole in our homes, says our design columnist. An unsightly void. Maybe millennials, who are rejecting TV sets, have the right idea?. title: Bringing Slapstick to Opera's Classic Death Scenes
summary: Joseph Keckler, the performance artist with a classically trained voice, brings opera highlights to life in his show 'Let Me Die.'. He has performed at Lincoln Center, the Pompidou Center in Paris-and at Weirdo Night at Zebulon, a hipster café in Los Angeles. The bass-baritone that resonates from his thin frame and baby face almost seems like an optical illusion. His versatile voice can climb to what he calls "this sort of theremin-like sound up at the top."

title: Mountain Homes With Steep Slopes and Price Tags, Too

title: The Cost and Benefit of Health-Insurance Companies
summary: We just need a transparent system that fits with the future of health care, not its past.. Chris Pope tries to make the argument that health insurers are the stewards of the health-care dollar, and that by saying "no," insurers prevent unnecessary claims and waste because there is so much money to be made from the reimbursement of medical services ("Be Grateful for Your Health-Insurance Company," op-ed, Sept. 12).

title: Mugabe Destroyed Zimbabwe's Property Rights
summary: It's true that Robert Mugabe's drive for a one-party state, his brutality and deep corruption were a significant part of Zimbabwe's economic collapse. But the signature blow that brought Zimbabwe's economy crashing down was the abandonment of property rights in 2000.. Regarding Jason L. Riley's otherwise excellent "A Too-Comfortable End for Robert Mugabe" (Upward Mobility, Sept. 11): It's true that Robert Mugabe's drive for a one-party state, his brutality and deep corruption were a significant part of Zimbabwe's economic collapse. But the signature blow that brought Zimbabwe's economy crashing down was the abandonment of property rights in 2000, which had previously been enshrined in its constitution.

title: Relatively Low Teacher Pay Reflects Market Demand
summary: There are more "qualified" teaching graduates looking for a job than there are openings in their desired location.. John E. Stafford asks why "starting salaries for public-school teachers in many states are under $40,000 a year" ("A High-Tech Schooling Guarantees Nothing," Letters, Sept. 11). The answer is supply and demand. There are more "qualified" teaching graduates looking for a job than there are openings in their desired location. Union protection and state-mandated benefits assure that placeholders stay in place. Market theory says that when there are more goods available than the market requires, the price goes down.

title: Hong Kong's Young See What Our Youth Do Not
summary: I found it increasingly ironic that the young people of Hong Kong are willing to sacrifice everything, including their lives if necessary, from the authoritarian fangs of communist Beijing, while young people in this country embrace radical socialism.. A six-month sabbatical in Venezuela could be influential.

title: Giants Bench Eli Manning for Daniel Jones
summary: The No. 6 overall pick in the 2019 draft will make his first career start against Tampa Bay in Week 3. After years of losing, awkwardness and politicking over what to do with an aging quarterback who led the franchise to two Super Bowl titles, the New York Giants finally made their long-anticipated move: They sent Eli Manning to the bench.

title: U.K.'s Top Court Hears Case Against Boris Johnson Suspending Parliament
summary: Prime minister is accused of using the shutdown to prevent scrutiny of his Brexit plan. LONDON-The U.K.'s highest court waded into Britain's Brexit drama as it began deliberations on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnson's decision to suspend Parliament this month was lawful.

title: People Need an Incentive to Use Strong Passwords. We Gave Them One.
summary: Warnings about the dangers of weak passwords aren't enough to change people's behavior, but a dachshund helps. It's tough to get people to behave in a particular way.

title: Taliban Suicide Attack Kills Dozens Near Site of Afghan President's Speech
summary: Blast leaves at least 26 people dead and wounds 42 others; second deadly explosion hits near U.S. Embassy in Kabul. KABUL-A Taliban suicide bomber aboard a motorcycle set off a blast at a security gate near a campaign speech by President Ashraf Ghani on Tuesday, killing dozens of people and heightening fears of even more bloodshed following the collapse of negotiations to end the Afghan war.

title: Kraft Heinz Shares Slide After 3G Trims Stake
summary: Brazilian private-equity firm sells about 9% of its stake in struggling food maker. The private-equity firm that helped create Kraft Heinz Co. has sold about 9% of its stake in the struggling food maker, a move that weighed on the company's shares Tuesday.

title: WeWork's Back Is Against a Wall
summary: As We Co. looks to restart its IPO later this year, features that cause shareholder dilution deserve closer scrutiny. We Co., the parent of office-sharing business WeWork, has more than one foot on its neck.

title: 'Downton Abbey' Star Hugh Bonneville Grew Up in an Edwardian Home That Felt Grand
summary: Despite a schoolteacher who stifled his enthusiasm, the British actor says he was 'determined to act'. Hugh Bonneville, 55, is an English actor who was in PBS's "Downton Abbey" and has appeared in "Notting Hill," "Paddington" and more than 35 other films. He will star in the "Downton Abbey" film, to be released Sept. 20. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Spotted Lanternfly vs. Pennsylvania: The Bug Is Winning
summary: Resume Subscription. The government sent out a message: Kill them all.

title: 'Nobody Has to Be Punished': Joe Biden's Economic Tap Dance
summary: Self-styled Middle Class Joe wants to improve programs, not create sweeping new ones. Is that enough for today's Democratic Party?. Joe Biden addressed the Poor People's Moral Action Congress in Washington in mid-June, decrying the country's "gigantic income inequality." The next day, he held a fundraiser at New York's Carlyle Hotel, assuring the Wall Street audience he wouldn't demonize the affluent.

title: Tehran Tries to Show High Costs of U.S.'s 'Maximum Pressure' Campaign
summary: Attack on Saudi oil industry, which administration blames on Iran, is a reminder of risks a Persian Gulf conflict poses for energy markets. BEIRUT-As the Trump administration has worked to choke off Iran's oil exports and strangle its economy, Tehran has sought to raise the costs of the U.S.'s "maximum pressure" campaign.

title: Tennessee Unveils Draft Plan to Convert Medicaid to Block Grants
summary: Proposal is first since Trump administration encouraged states to pitch overhauls of the entitlement's funding. Tennessee on Tuesday released a draft plan to overhaul funding for its Medicaid program, a proposal that would convert the open-ended federal funding it receives into a lump sum that would increase on a per-person basis if enrollment climbs.

title: WeWork Wants to Be More Than Office Space. It Hasn't Had Much Success.
summary: Company's rental-apartment venture struggles to make money, while other side businesses have fizzled.

title: AT&T CEO Defends Expected Successor After Activist Attack
summary: Telecom boss said newly named chief operating officer John Stankey was the right pick. AT&T Inc. Chief Executive Randall Stephenson defended his strategy and likely successor in his first public remarks since an activist hedge fund challenged the company to change direction.

title: Foxconn Founder Pulls Out of Presidential Race in Taiwan
summary: Decision by billionaire Terry Gou could shift election's focus to social issues and the island's independence. Taiwanese billionaire Terry Gou, founder of iPhone assembler Foxconn Technology Group, said he wouldn't run for the island's presidency, a surprise decision that will alter the contours of what will be a hotly contested election.

title: Smoking Ban Lights Up Sales at Rare Cigarette-Friendly Bars
summary: Resume Subscription. At first glance, Karma Lounge looks like any dive bar in Manhattan's East Village. It has a window box packed with plastic daffodils, a black-painted facade and the usual sidewalk board advertising $5 happy hour beers. The one surprise-a tiny door sign bearing a phrase seldom seen these days: "Smoking Permitted."

title: Public Companies Consider New Controls to Prepare For Audit Rule
summary: Expanded auditor report offers investors a window into a company's most complicated issues. Companies preparing for a new auditing rule are unearthing knotty internal issues, and these revelations are prompting executives to strengthen internal controls.

title: 'Big Bang Theory' to Show on HBO's New Streaming Service
summary: It is the latest in a string of deals for popular reruns as services battle for content. HBO Max, the new direct-to-consumer streaming service AT&T Inc.'s WarnerMedia is launching next spring, has struck a deal for streaming rights to reruns of the hit comedy "The Big Bang Theory," which ended a 12-year run on CBS in May.

title: U.S. Army Tries New Recruiting Tactics After Missing Targets
summary: Largest branch of military struggles in a strong economy; a pilot program in Chicago. CHICAGO-The U.S. Army is experimenting with new recruiting tactics as it struggles to connect with young people who have other job options in a strong economy.

title: Stocks to Watch: Anheuser-Busch, Kraft Heinz, Corning and Sony
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Tuesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: A '66 Skylark Stands Out in a Brigade of Buicks
summary: Resume Subscription. Jimmy Shiels, 54, a general contractor from Franklin, Mass., on his 1966 Buick Skylark Gran Sport collection, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: WeWork's Parent Postpones IPO
summary: We Co. scraps roadshow planned for this week amid investor doubts about the company's valuation and concerns about corporate governance. WeWork's parent postponed its initial public offering after investors questioned how much the company is worth and raised concerns about its corporate governance.

title: Photos: A 1966 Buick Skylark That Still Sings
summary: Extreme enthusiasm for the Gran Sport, a 1960s classic, shows in this standout from a Massachusetts collection.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Software-Development Startup GitLab Raises $268 Million
summary: Company's valuation has grown to $2.75 billion, CEO says, along with demand for its tools from corporate IT teams. GitLab Inc., a fully remote company that sells tools for software developers within a single application, said Tuesday that it has raised $268 million in new venture-capital funding thanks to strong demand for its products from corporations.

title: Amazon Music Streaming Goes High-Definition
summary: New service-at a higher price-is a challenge to Spotify, Apple and Tidal. Amazon.com Inc. is introducing a high-resolution version of its music service, making it the first major subscription-streaming player to offer digital sound quality on par with CDs.

title: Comcast's 'Peacock' Becomes Latest Entrant in Streaming Scramble
summary: NBCUniversal's streaming service is expected to be free to Comcast's American cable subscribers. Comcast Corp.'s new streaming service, called "Peacock," will debut in April with a slate of original programming featuring stars like Alec Baldwin and Demi Moore, in addition to exclusive streaming rights to popular NBC staples from "Parks and Recreation" to "The Office."

title: Debate Over Kavanaugh Is Reignited
summary: Resume Subscription. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: Walmart Likely Discriminated Against Female Workers, EEOC Says
summary: Retailer tells agency it is willing to engage in conciliatory process. Walmart Inc. likely discriminated against 178 female workers by paying less or denying promotions because of their gender, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said in memos viewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: GM Strikes Don't Pack Economic Punch They Once Did
summary: Still, prolonged work stoppage would ripple through local economies, could lead to job losses elsewhere. The United Auto Workers strike against General Motors Co. could detract further from the U.S. economy at a time of mounting global uncertainty, but it would take a lengthy stoppage to inflict widespread pain, economists say.

title: The Team Poised to Play Spoiler in the Postseason
summary: The Yankees, Astros and Dodgers are considered baseball's superteams. But the Braves have quietly built up a powerhouse in Atlanta.. This is the age of the superteam in professional sports, and baseball is no exception. Three teams-the New York Yankees, Houston Astros and Los Angeles Dodgers-could finish the regular season with 105 wins, something that has never happened before. It has created the perception that the upcoming playoffs are little more than an anticlimactic undercard before an inevitable World Series matchup between two of these top dogs.

title: How to Use Parental Controls From Apple, Google and Amazon
summary: Parents who want to set content filters and control who their kids text should start with the built-in settings on their devices. Many parents ask how they can keep tabs on their children online without shelling out a lot of money-and without major headaches, especially when juggling multiple devices for multiple children. The first step isn't to buy expensive software, but to look at the devices themselves.

title: A New Central Bank Approach: Pay Banks to Lend
summary: The ECB has said it would both pay a higher rate of interest on deposits and charge a lower fee for lending. If you think negative interest rates are weird, brace yourself. The European Central Bank is about to start lending to some banks at less than it pays them for putting money on deposit.

title: Bud Brewer Takes Another Shot at Asian IPO
summary: Listing could raise up to $7.6 billion, making it the world's second-largest IPO this year, after Uber's. The world's largest brewer is taking a second shot at listing its Asian business, seeking to raise as much as $7.6 billion in Hong Kong, even as the city reels from a summer of protests and from trade tensions between the U.S. and China.

title: Venezuela Quietly Loosens Grip on Market, Tempering Economic Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. CARACAS, Venezuela-President Nicolás Maduro's authoritarian government, long a practitioner of tight state control of the economy, has quietly and cautiously begun implementing free-market policies to tame hyperinflation and correct an economic contraction worse than America's Great Depression. So far, that approach is providing a sliver of light to the moribund economy.

title: E-Commerce Made Warehouses Hot. Trade War Could Cool Them Down.
summary: Slowing business investment, weaker growth, and uncertainty created by the trade dispute are said to be weighing on the sector. The rise of e-commerce has pushed up warehouse rents and made industrial buildings one of the hottest sectors in real estate. Now, a slowing economy and trade dispute between the U.S. and China threaten that boom.

title: Chip Makers Are Seeking More 5G Connections
summary: Expensive phones on complex networks spell opportunity for Broadcom, Qualcomm, Qorvo and Skyworks. Sales of 5G wireless phones may be slow to take off. But the complexity of those phones is going to be a boon for some chip makers sooner than later.

title: HSBC's Geopolitical Balancing Act
summary: The London-listed bank's stock trades at a big premium even as its role funneling Western capital to China via Hong Kong becomes uncomfortably political. When investors worry about geopolitical risk, they tend to think of oil producers or car makers exposed to tariff threats. One company that gets less attention than it should is HSBC .

title: China's Economy Aches All Over as Beijing Seeks Trade Fix With the U.S.
summary: Industrial output and retail sales growth slow, but recent goodwill gestures by Beijing and Washington suggest tensions are easing. BEIJING-Economic activity in China cooled further in August, testing Beijing's tolerance for slower growth as it seeks to ease trade tensions with the U.S.

title: Fashion Designer Thakoon is Back With a Direct-to-Consumer Line-And Everything Costs Less Than $300
summary: After shuttering his eponymous fashion label for two years, Thakoon is back with a new concept under the same name, betting that customers want affordable, quality wardrobe essentials with a designer edge. Fashion designer Thakoon Panichgul says his friends aren't buying $500 dresses anymore. It's a price point they once didn't blink at, he explains, but having more options than ever before has changed the way consumers understand luxury. "Before, it was almost like, luxury equals this $1,500 dress from this designer and you better go get it because there aren't that many of them," he says. "It's almost like [the customer] had been dictated to. Now she's doing the research online, she's informing herself and she knows exactly what she wants."

title: Uber Seeks to Build Up Freight Business
summary: New trucking services, a headquarters in Chicago are part of an increased push into freight transportation. Uber Technologies Inc. is digging deeper into the freight business, ramping up hiring at a planned new hub in Chicago and rolling out logistics services even as its core ride-hailing business continues to post steep losses.

title: iPhone 11, 11 Pro, 11 Pro Max Review: The Battery Life We've Been Dying For
summary: The new iPhones have improved cameras, but our columnist is betting you'll care most about the extra juice. This year I've written two iPhone reviews. This one has my testing results of the new iPhone 11 models. The other, found here, is an advice column for the many readers we've heard from who have older phones-I'm looking at you, iPhone Sixers!

title: The Upgrader's Guide to the iPhone 11 (and All the Other Choices)
summary: A guide for people upgrading their old iPhone. After all, the latest and greatest aren't your only options. This year I've written two iPhone reviews. Read this if you have an older iPhone and are unsure about what comes next. If you'd also like to know more about my testing of the new iPhone 11 and iPhone 11 Pro models-particularly their camera and battery life-go here.

title: Banks Fund Identity Verification Startup Trulioo's Expansion
summary: Goldman Sachs joined Citi Ventures and other banks' VC arms in backing the Vancouver-based startup. Several Wall Street banks and financial firms have invested 60 million Canadian dollars ($45.2 million) in identity verification startup Trulioo Information Services Inc.

title: Why Fed Officials Aren't Saying More About the Interest Rate Outlook
summary: Faced with rising uncertainty, Chairman Jerome Powell must toe the line between disappointing markets that expect more stimulus, overpromising steps that lack broad support. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell is leading his colleagues to cut interest rates by a quarter percentage point at their meeting this week, for the second time in as many months, to cushion the U.S. economy against a slowdown from the U.S.-China trade war and weak growth abroad.

title: World Catching Up With China on Surveillance Tech
summary: China leads world in facial-recognition and other new surveillance technologies, report says. WASHINGTON-China leads the world in facial-recognition and other new surveillance technologies, with its own government using the tools at home and Huawei Technologies Co. exporting them globally, according to a new report by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

title: Cardinal Pell Seeks to Appeal Sex-Abuse Conviction to Australia's Top Court
summary: This is the last chance for the former Vatican finance chief to have his conviction overturned. MELBOURNE, Australia-Lawyers for Cardinal George Pell have applied to Australia's top court to appeal the former Vatican finance chief's conviction for child sexual abuse.

title: Why Some Banks Are Ditching Their State Regulators
summary: Fifth Third is the latest bank to switch from state regulators to the OCC, which has struck a friendlier tone under the Trump administration. WASHINGTON-A national bank regulator is trumpeting his agency's oversight as a good business proposition.

title: Effort to Stem Deaths Among Children Falls Short, Report Says
summary: Bill Gates says slow progress in developing countries shows there 'will still be a dramatic level of inequality' for child mortality, education at end of century. Nearly two-thirds of children in developing countries live in villages, cities or regions where deaths under 5 years of age aren't declining rapidly enough to meet United Nations goals, according to a new report released Tuesday. .

title: Pork Plants to Speed Slaughter Under USDA Rule Changes
summary: Food-safety groups and unions say the new rules increase risks for workers, consumers. The U.S. Department of Agriculture set new rules to shift more food-safety responsibilities from government inspectors to workers in pork plants, allowing meatpackers to speed up processing lines.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: International Panel Set to Criticize FAA's Approval Process for Boeing 737 MAX Jets
summary: Panel's recommendations could set the stage for major changes to longstanding jet-certification rules. A panel of international air-safety regulators is finishing a report expected to criticize the initial U.S. approval process for Boeing Co. 's 737 MAX jets, according to people briefed on the conclusions, while urging a wide-ranging reassessment of how complex automated systems should be certified on future airliners.

title: California Governor Joins Those Wanting to Ban Flavored E-Cigarettes
summary: Gavin Newsom says he would sign a bill banning the devices if the legislature sent one up. SAN FRANCISCO-California Gov. Gavin Newsom said he would sign a bill banning flavored e-cigarettes if the state legislature sent one his way.

title: Antitrust Enforcers Signal Discord Over Probes of Big Tech
summary: FTC letter to Justice Department raises concerns about the agencies' recent interactions. WASHINGTON-Bad blood between the U.S. government entities investigating the giants of the tech industry has grown more intense with the delivery of a letter from one agency to the other that might be considered the equivalent of a brushback pitch.

title: Warren Pitches Attack on Corruption
summary: In New York address, Democratic hopeful calls for further restrictions on lobbyists. NEW YORK-Elizabeth Warren cemented a fight against corruption as the argument underpinning her presidential campaign, telling thousands gathered in this liberal bastion that "giant corporations have bought off our government."

title: Oil Prices Log Historic Rally After Saudi Attack
summary: Prices climb 15% as some analysts anticipate supply shortages, though plentiful stockpiles could cap future gains. Oil prices logged one of their largest rallies ever, highlighting anxiety that weekend attacks on the heart of Saudi Arabia's oil industry could cause supply shortages and pose a new threat to the global economy.

title: 'SNL' Fires New Cast Member After Slurs Surface Online
summary: Comedian Shane Gillis was slated to begin on the NBC show this month. "Saturday Night Live" on Monday fired a new cast member slated to start on the NBC show in its fall season, following days of controversy over his use of racial and homophobic slurs.

title: Inflation Bonds Lead Gains in U.S. Government Debt
summary: Gains halted a selloff that had driven the 10-year yield higher in five consecutive sessions. U.S. government bonds that offer investors protection against inflation rallied Monday, powered by concerns that a surge in oil prices would raise consumer prices after an attack on the heart of Saudi Arabia's oil industry.

title: Corning Cuts Sales Forecast as Demand Slows
summary: Glassmaker says TV manufacturers are purchasing panels more conservatively. Specialty glassmaker Corning Inc. lowered its sales and volume expectations for materials found in TV sets and optical-communication cables, citing weaker demand.
